Dear mr. fagan,

To deny the uncertainties of the climate-CO2 relationship is to deny the science behind it.

Let's begin with equilibrium climate sensitivity. Decades of research after the Charney report have not reduced the range of climate sensitivity estimates; they have increased it, from 2-4 deg C/2X CO2 to 1.5 to 4.5 deg C/2X CO2.

I see Lindzen calculates < 1 deg C/ 2X CO2, whereas the most whacko models in the CMIP-5 figure 4.7 deg C/2X CO2.

Does that not constitute a bit of uncertainty?

According to Ch 9 of the UN IPCC's AR5, climate models using the same input do not predict SAT within + or - 3 deg C, with the multi-model mean well above observations. Yet we are required to believe that "climate change" is "settled science"?

I think not.

Or consider the "social cost of carbon." I see numbers ranging from McKittrick's -$5/tonne (a net benefit) to Stern-type numbers on the order of $110/tonne.

I bit of uncertainty there, would you not agree?

Our host Andy has said many times that the best scientists are convinced that SOMETHING will happen due to added CO2 in the atmosphere. However, the magnitude and timing of that something remain uncertain.

It is the uncertainty on the pace, magnitude and nature of climate change due to added anthropogenic CO2 that makes this a "wicked problem", in Andy's words.

I agree.

Sorry, JonathanG, but your interpretation is off the mark.  When polls' margins of error are reported, they typically refer to a 95 percent "confidence interval" (CI), which is the CI associated with about 2 standard deviations from the observed mean or proportion.  It very rarely refers to a 68 percent CI, which would be consistent with 1 standard deviation.  If you read the linked paper, this is also what is said there.  Bottom line:  This Upshot piece is correct as is.

You are discussing standard error. MoE when used in polls is defined as half the width of the Confidence Interval. For most polls, the CI is 95%, thus for n=~1000, MoE is 3%, for a CI width of 6%. The SE for a 95% CI is half the MoE. The Times stated it correctly.

Actually, what is called "the margin of error" *is* the half-wdith of the 95% confidence interval. The standard error (of the sample estimate p of the population proportion P) is roughly half that. So if the MOE is 3 points, the standard error is 1.5 points.

The reporting here makes a fundamental error in the first paragraph. Putting aside any systematic errors, when polling 1000 people the statistical error reported as "+/- 3" is the standard deviation (or sigma). The result of this poll is an estimate of the true value. The likelihood of the true value lying within a range of +/- one sigma is 68%, not 95%. The 95% confidence interval corresponds to +/- two sigma, which is +/- 6% in a poll of 1000 people. This is correctly described in the abstract of the linked paper, but is misstated here.

A related point is that people often tend to over-interpret the stated accuracy of polls. Because polls report their uncertainty as +/- one sigma, this means that even if there were no systematic uncertainties, we should expect the final outcome to lie within the stated uncertainty interval only in approximately 2 out of every 3 polls.

MyThreeCents: Re: "Did YOU know where Aleppo is before this war began?"
How is this question relevant? Gary Johnson didn't know where Aleppo is as late as three weeks ago.

Re: "Of course I'd prefer that Johnson know where Aleppo is, but the more important point is: 'Why in the world should we be focused on Aleppo?'"

Because it's a disaster and people are hurting. Why does that mean nothing to you?

Re: "How about 'Chicago,' or 'St. Louis" or 'Denver' or 'Dallas.' I certainly hope Johnson knows where those cities are, and I'm confident he does."

I'm not at all confident he does: really. Yes, he's probably heard of them, but could he find them on an unlabeled map? I doubt it. In any case, the United States is not alone in the universe. One way or another it has take account of the world around it.

We DO need to know (a lot) about Aleppo and every other place on earth. Especially the president. We live in a very inter-connected world where people's ideas and actions across the world have direct consequences for us.

We do not live on an island where we can pull up a drawbridge, and we never did. Just look at Zika, global warming, 9/11, oil prices. We are by default engaged in the world, so we need leaders who can engage intelligently.

"Why would anyone listen to Gary Johnson's pronouncements about Syria when he didn't even know what or where Aleppo is?"

Did YOU know where Aleppo is before this war began?

Of course I'd prefer that Johnson know where Aleppo is, but the more important point is: "Why in the world should we be focused on Aleppo?"

How about "Chicago," or "St. Louis" or "Denver" or "Dallas." I certainly hope Johnson knows where those cities are, and I'm confident he does.
